text.headline: A changing Boyle heights
text.text: A changing Boyle Heights is not a new story for L.A. But are new developments meeting the needs of the community? Who is getting pushed out and how? Where are they going? KPCC looks at stories past and present in a neighborhood that has resisted gentrification, but is seeing new developments pop up all over town.

text.headline: Elvira Barrales
text.text: Elvira Barrales has lived in her rent-controlled Boyle Heights apartment for 16 years with her four children. In April she received notice that two of her children needed to go under threat of eviction. She fought her eviction notice in court and won. Meanwhile, the same landlord is listing apartments in the same building as “art district adjacent” for $1,000 per month. Read the full story at kpcc.org.

text.headline: “Arts District” Apartment for rent
text.text: In the same building where Elvira Barrales and her family lives, there is an vacant apartment listed at $1,000 per month. It’s marketed on Craigslist as an “arts district adjacent” apartment. Barrales has lived on the property for 16 years paying $630 per month.

text.headline: 'Why rent downtown when you could own in Boyle Heights?'
text.text: In 2014, Adaptive Realty marketed a bike tour through Boyle Heights to potential buyers, which sparked backlash from the community. The flier advertising to tour said: "Why rent downtown when you could own in Boyle Heights?" The bike tour was later cancelled and the real estate agency apologized, but the community was already stirred. One activist in Boyle Heights said no good can come from gentrification. Read the full story at kpcc.org.

text.headline: 11-story Sears building
text.text: An 11-story Sears Roebuck store stood tall in Boyle Heights since the 1920s until it closed. Developers are now creating a mixed residential, retail and office space. Boyle Heights residents criticized the new development’s lack of affordable housing. Read the full story at kpcc.org.

text.headline: Mariachi Plaza
text.text: Mariachi Plaza in Boyle Heights is a local landmark, known for generations of musicians waiting for gigs. Metro owns the land and wants to develop the area adjacent to the Plaza. Plans for retail and medical office space were tossed out after residents objected, and now Metro is taking suggestions from the community. Everything from grocery stores to a Mariachi museum has been suggested. The musicians fear that more could cause the traditions and soul of Mariachi Plaza to be lost. Read the full story at kpcc.org.

text.headline: Proyecto jardín
text.text: Since January, members of the Boyle Heights community have been conducting a 24/7 sit-in to keep a cultural spot under their care. Proyecto Jardin is a community garden on land owned by White Memorial Medical Center. When the garden’s lease was up, White Memorial did not want to extend the lease on the terms they had with the garden managers for 15 years, wanting to change things, including the name from Proyecto Jardin to White Memorial Memorial Garden. “For many of us, it's indicative of sort of devaluing our culture and all of the sweat equity, the time, the work, the effort that's been made to turn that into a space that's inviting," one activist said. This is an ongoing case between activists resisting the loss of their garden and the medical center. Read the full story at kpcc.org.

text.headline: Carnitas Michoacan No. 3
text.text: For 33 years, Carnitas Michoacan was the 24-hour neighborhood go-to spot after church or when everything else was closed. Unlike the unwavering certainty that Carnitas always provided for 2 a.m. nachos and tacos, for Orlando Orta, who has worked there for 27 years — and other employees —  the future is less clear. The restaurant is closing down and will be replaced with a Panda Express, eliminating yet another Boyle Heights institution and leaving all its employees to join the workforce again.
